segment.source: Create a custom Windows PE boot image with Configuration Manager (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a custom Windows PE boot image with Configuration Manager (Windows 10)

segment.source: In Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager, you can create custom Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) boot images that include extra components and features.
segment.target: In Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager, you can create custom Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) boot images that include extra components and features.

segment.source: Create a custom Windows PE boot image with Configuration Manager
segment.target: Create a custom Windows PE boot image with Configuration Manager

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: In Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager, you can create custom Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) boot images that include extra components and features.
segment.target: In Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager, you can create custom Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) boot images that include extra components and features.

segment.source: This topic shows you how to create a custom Windows PE 5.0 boot image with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 wizard.
segment.target: This topic shows you how to create a custom Windows PE 5.0 boot image with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 wizard.

segment.source: You can also add the Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT) 10 to the boot image as part of the boot image creation process.
segment.target: You can also add the Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT) 10 to the boot image as part of the boot image creation process.

segment.source: For the purposes of this topic, we will use two machines: DC01 and CM01.
segment.target: For the purposes of this topic, we will use two machines: DC01 and CM01.

segment.source: DC01 is a domain controller and CM01 is a machine running Windows Server 2012 R2 Standard.
segment.target: DC01 is a domain controller and CM01 is a machine running Windows Server 2012 R2 Standard.

segment.source: Both are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.
segment.target: Both are members of the domain contoso.com for the fictitious Contoso Corporation.

segment.source: For more details on the setup for this topic, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: For more details on the setup for this topic, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.source: Add DaRT 10 files and prepare to brand the boot image
segment.target: Add DaRT 10 files and prepare to brand the boot image

segment.source: The steps below outline the process for adding DaRT 10 installation files to the MDT installation directory.
segment.target: The steps below outline the process for adding DaRT 10 installation files to the MDT installation directory.

segment.source: You also copy a custom background image to be used later.
segment.target: You also copy a custom background image to be used later.

segment.source: We assume you have downloaded Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack (MDOP) 2015 and copied the x64 version of MSDaRT10.msi to the C:SetupDaRT 10 folder.
segment.target: We assume you have downloaded Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack (MDOP) 2015 and copied the x64 version of MSDaRT10.msi to the C:SetupDaRT 10 folder.

segment.source: We also assume you have created a custom background image and saved it in C:SetupBranding on CM01.
segment.target: We also assume you have created a custom background image and saved it in C:SetupBranding on CM01.

segment.source: In this section, we use a custom background image named ContosoBackground.bmp.
segment.target: In this section, we use a custom background image named ContosoBackground.bmp.

segment.source: Install DaRT 10 (C:SetupDaRT 10MSDaRT10.msi) using the default settings.
segment.target: Install DaRT 10 (C:SetupDaRT 10MSDaRT10.msi) using the default settings.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, navigate to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft DaRTv10 folder.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, navigate to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft DaRTv10 folder.

segment.source: Copy the Toolsx64.cab file to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft Deployment ToolkitTemplatesDistributionToolsx64 folder.
segment.target: Copy the Toolsx64.cab file to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft Deployment ToolkitTemplatesDistributionToolsx64 folder.

segment.source: Copy the Toolsx86.cab file to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft Deployment ToolkitTemplatesDistributionToolsx86 folder.
segment.target: Copy the Toolsx86.cab file to the C:Program FilesMicrosoft Deployment ToolkitTemplatesDistributionToolsx86 folder.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, navigate to the C:Setup folder.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, navigate to the C:Setup folder.

segment.source: Copy the Branding folder to E:SourcesOSD.
segment.target: Copy the Branding folder to E:SourcesOSD.

segment.source: Create a boot image for Configuration Manager using the MDT wizard
segment.target: Create a boot image for Configuration Manager using the MDT wizard

segment.source: By using the MDT wizard to create the boot image in Configuration Manager, you gain additional options for adding components and features to the boot image.
segment.target: By using the MDT wizard to create the boot image in Configuration Manager, you gain additional options for adding components and features to the boot image.

segment.source: In this section, you create a boot image for Configuration Manager using the MDT wizard.
segment.target: In this section, you create a boot image for Configuration Manager using the MDT wizard.

segment.source: Using the Configuration Manager Console, in the Software Library workspace, expand Operating Systems, right-click Boot Images, and select Create Boot Image using MDT.
segment.target: Using the Configuration Manager Console, in the Software Library workspace, expand Operating Systems, right-click Boot Images, and select Create Boot Image using MDT.

segment.source: On the Package Source page, in the Package source folder to be created (UNC Path): text box, type CM01Sources$OSDBootZero Touch WinPE x64 and click Next.
segment.target: On the Package Source page, in the Package source folder to be created (UNC Path): text box, type CM01Sources$OSDBootZero Touch WinPE x64 and click Next.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The Zero Touch WinPE x64 folder does not yet exist.
segment.target: The Zero Touch WinPE x64 folder does not yet exist.

segment.source: The folder will be created later by the wizard.
segment.target: The folder will be created later by the wizard.

segment.source: On the General Settings page, assign the name Zero Touch WinPE x64 and click Next.
segment.target: On the General Settings page, assign the name Zero Touch WinPE x64 and click Next.

segment.source: On the Options page, select the x64 platform, and click Next.
segment.target: On the Options page, select the x64 platform, and click Next.

segment.source: On the Components page, in addition to the default selected Microsoft Data Access Components (MDAC/ADO) support, select the Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolkit (DaRT) check box.
segment.target: On the Components page, in addition to the default selected Microsoft Data Access Components (MDAC/ADO) support, select the Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolkit (DaRT) check box.

segment.source: figure 15
segment.target: figure 15

segment.source: Figure 15.
segment.target: Figure 15.

segment.source: Add the DaRT component to the Configuration Manager boot image.
segment.target: Add the DaRT component to the Configuration Manager boot image.

segment.source: On the Customization page, select the Use a custom background bitmap file check box, and in the UNC path: text box, browse to CM01Sources$OSDBranding ContosoBackground.bmp.
segment.target: On the Customization page, select the Use a custom background bitmap file check box, and in the UNC path: text box, browse to CM01Sources$OSDBranding ContosoBackground.bmp.

segment.source: Then click Next twice.
segment.target: Then click Next twice.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: It will take a few minutes to generate the boot image.
segment.target: It will take a few minutes to generate the boot image.

segment.source: Distribute the boot image to the CM01 distribution point by selecting the Boot images node, right-clicking the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image, and selecting Distribute Content.
segment.target: Distribute the boot image to the CM01 distribution point by selecting the Boot images node, right-clicking the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image, and selecting Distribute Content.

segment.source: In the Distribute Content Wizard, add the CM01 distribution point, and complete the wizard.
segment.target: In the Distribute Content Wizard, add the CM01 distribution point, and complete the wizard.

segment.source: Using Configuration Manager Trace, review the E:Program FilesMicrosoft Configuration ManagerLogsdistmgr.log file.
segment.target: Using Configuration Manager Trace, review the E:Program FilesMicrosoft Configuration ManagerLogsdistmgr.log file.

segment.source: Do not continue until you can see that the boot image is distributed.
segment.target: Do not continue until you can see that the boot image is distributed.

segment.source: Look for the line that reads STATMSG: ID=2301.
segment.target: Look for the line that reads STATMSG: ID=2301.

segment.source: You also can view Content Status in the Configuration Manager Console by selecting the Zero Touch WinPE x86 boot image.
segment.target: You also can view Content Status in the Configuration Manager Console by selecting the Zero Touch WinPE x86 boot image.

segment.source: figure 16
segment.target: figure 16

segment.source: Figure 16.
segment.target: Figure 16.

segment.source: Content status for the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image.
segment.target: Content status for the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image.

segment.source: Using the Configuration Manager Console, right-click the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image and select Properties.
segment.target: Using the Configuration Manager Console, right-click the Zero Touch WinPE x64 boot image and select Properties.

segment.source: In the Data Source tab, select the Deploy this boot image from the PXE-enabled distribution point check box, and click OK.
segment.target: In the Data Source tab, select the Deploy this boot image from the PXE-enabled distribution point check box, and click OK.

segment.source: Using Configuration Manager Trace, review the E:Program FilesMicrosoft Configuration ManagerLogsdistmgr.log file and look for this text: Expanding PS10000B to E:RemoteInstallSMSImages.
segment.target: Using Configuration Manager Trace, review the E:Program FilesMicrosoft Configuration ManagerLogsdistmgr.log file and look for this text: Expanding PS10000B to E:RemoteInstallSMSImages.

segment.source: Review the E:RemoteInstallSMSImages folder.
segment.target: Review the E:RemoteInstallSMSImages folder.

segment.source: You should see three folders containing boot images.
segment.target: You should see three folders containing boot images.

segment.source: Two are from the default boot images, and the third folder (PS10000B) is from your new boot image with DaRT.
segment.target: Two are from the default boot images, and the third folder (PS10000B) is from your new boot image with DaRT.
